questions.q: If A = {1, 2} and B = {x, y}, then the Cartesian product A × B has:
questions.explanation: The Cartesian product A × B is the set of all ordered pairs (a, b) where a is in A and b is in B.

questions.q: If f: R → R is defined by f(x) = x³ - 3x and g(x) = x + 2, then (f ∘ g)(1) equals:
questions.explanation: First find g(1) = 1 + 2 = 3. Then find f(3) = 3³ - 3(3) = 27 - 9 = 18.

questions.q: The function f(x) = 2x + 3 has inverse function:
questions.explanation: To find the inverse, set y = 2x + 3, swap x and y (x = 2y + 3), and solve for y: y = (x - 3)/2.

questions.q: For which function is f⁻¹(x) = f(x)?
questions.explanation: The function f(x) = 1/x is its own inverse because 1/(1/x) = x. f(x) = x also satisfies this, but 1/x is a more classic example of a self-inverse function in this context.

questions.q: Let D(x) mean 'x is a doctor' and H(x) mean 'x works in a hospital'. What is the symbolic form of 'Not all doctors work in hospitals'?
questions.explanation: ¬∀x(P) is logically equivalent to ∃x(¬P). So 'Not all doctors work in hospitals' is the same as 'There exists a doctor who does not work in a hospital.'

questions.q: If C(x) means 'x is a car' and F(x) means 'x is fast', which symbolizes 'Only fast vehicles are cars'?
questions.explanation: 'Only A are B' means if it is B, then it must be A. So 'Only fast vehicles are cars' means if it is a car, it is fast.

questions.q: Let P(x,y) mean 'x is greater than y'. What is the meaning of ∀x ∃y P(x,y)?
options: For every x, there is some y that is greater than x
For every x, there is some y that x is greater than
There exists an x that is greater than all y
There exists a y that is greater than all x
questions.explanation: The statement reads: 'For every x, there exists a y such that x is greater than y.'

questions.q: If P(x) means 'x is a prime number' and Q(x) means 'x is odd', which statement means 'Some prime numbers are not odd'?
questions.explanation: 'Some' indicates an existential quantifier (∃), and we are looking for an x that is both a prime and NOT odd.

questions.q: If P(x) means 'x is a student' and Q(x) means 'x studies hard', what does ∃x(P(x) ∧ Q(x)) mean in English?
questions.explanation: The existential quantifier (∃) translates to 'Some' or 'There exists'.

questions.q: Let P(x) be 'x is a positive number' and Q(x) be 'x is less than 10'. Which statement represents 'All positive numbers less than 10 are integers' (let R(x) be 'x is an integer')?
questions.explanation: The phrase 'All [conditions] are [property]' is represented as ∀x(Conditions(x) → Property(x)).

questions.q: If P(x) is the statement 'x speaks French' and Q(x) is 'x knows Python', what is the logical equivalent of ¬∀x (P(x) → Q(x))?
options: Everyone speaks French and knows Python.
There is someone who speaks French but does not know Python.
There is someone who does not speak French and knows Python.
Everyone who knows Python does not speak French.
questions.explanation: The negation of 'All P are Q' is 'Some P are not Q'. In logic: ¬∀x(P(x) → Q(x)) ≡ ∃x(P(x) ∧ ¬Q(x)).

questions.q: Which expression represents: 'There is a computer on the network that has not received a virus from any other computer'?
questions.explanation: We need an x that is a computer (C(x)) AND for all y, x did not get a virus from y (¬V(x,y)).

questions.q: Let L(x, y) be 'x loves y.' What does ∃x (L(x, Logic) ∧ ∀y ((y ≠ x) → ¬L(y, Logic))) mean?
options: Everyone loves Logic except one person.
Someone loves Logic and Logic loves no one.
There is a person who loves only Logic.
questions.explanation: This is the standard logical form for uniqueness: there exists an x who loves Logic, and for any other person y, that person does not love Logic.

questions.q: Express 'The sum of two positive integers is always positive' using quantifiers over the domain of Integers Z.
questions.explanation: The statement applies to all pairs x, y. If both are positive, then their sum is positive.

questions.q: Let P(x) be a predicate. Which statement is logically equivalent to ¬∃x ∀y (P(x) ∨ P(y))?
questions.explanation: Using De Morgan's laws for quantifiers: ¬∃ becomes ∀¬, and ¬∀ becomes ∃¬. The inside ¬(P(x) ∨ P(y)) becomes (¬P(x) ∧ ¬P(y)).

questions.q: Translate: 'No one works for every company.'
questions.explanation: 'No one' (¬∃x) 'works for every company' (∀y W(x, y)).

questions.q: Analyze the logical steps: ∀x (P(x) → Q(x)), ¬Q(a), P(a) → Q(a) [Rule X], ¬P(a) [Rule Y]. Identify Rule X and Rule Y.
options: X: Universal Generalization, Y: Modus Ponens
X: Universal Instantiation, Y: Modus Tollens
X: Existential Instantiation, Y: Modus Tollens
X: Universal Instantiation, Y: Disjunctive Syllogism
questions.explanation: X is Universal Instantiation (applying the general rule to a specific 'a'). Y is Modus Tollens (if P→Q and ¬Q, then ¬P).

questions.q: To prove 'For all integers n, if n² is odd, then n is odd' using Proof by Contraposition, what is the correct initial assumption?
options: Assume n is odd, and n² is even
questions.explanation: Contraposition proves 'If ¬Q, then ¬P'. Here, Q is 'n is odd', so ¬Q is 'n is even'.

questions.q: Identify the logical structure of: 'Suppose ¬R is true. We demonstrate that this implies ¬P ∨ ¬Q.'
questions.explanation: The statement to prove is (P ∧ Q) → R. The contrapositive is ¬R → ¬(P ∧ Q), which is ¬R → (¬P ∨ ¬Q).

questions.q: Determine the negation of the statement: 'There is a student in the class who has taken every course offered.'
options: Every student in the class has taken every course offered.
There is a student who has not taken any course offered.
For every student, there is a course they have not taken.
No student has taken any course.
questions.explanation: The statement is ∃s ∀c T(s, c). The negation is ¬∃s ∀c T(s, c) ≡ ∀s ∃c ¬T(s, c).
